title: Get started with gecevar
text: Install development version gecevar GitHub devtools::install_github("ghislainv/gecevar")

title: Get started with gecevar
text: First thing import gecevar terra libraries.

title: Get started with gecevar
text: example, take New Caledonia example. ’s island near Australia New Zealand. need begin get EPSG code New Caledonia. can found epsg.io. Beware keep EPSG code functions gecevar package. output vector length 5. First element character extent New Caledonia according EPSG:3163. following four elements extent latitude longitude coordinates (EPSG:4326).
code: name <- "New Caledonia" epsg <- 3163 all_extent <- transform_shp_country_extent(EPSG = epsg,                                            country_name = name) extent <- all_extent[1] extent_latlon <- as.numeric(all_extent[2:5])

title: Get started with gecevar
text: One variable protected area named WDPA downloaded file. variable need identification country name. Make sure country name available www.protectedplanet.net. Otherwise leave country_name = NULL. can look variable names raster. can plot data, eg. elevation.
code: environ_path <- get_env_variables(extent_latlon = extent_latlon,                                   extent = extent,                                   EPSG = epsg,                                    country_name = "New Caledonia",                                   destination = here("vignettes",                                                      "get_started_files"),                                   resolution = 1000,                                   rm_download = FALSE,                                   gisBase = NULL) r_env <- rast(environ_path) names(r_env) plot(r_env$elevation, range = c(0, 2000), main = "Elevation (m)",      cex.main = 2, plg = list(cex = 1), pax = list(cex.axis = 1))

title: Get started with gecevar
text: Climatic variables extract chelsa-climate.org. get get_chelsa_current function many variables. Variables give average value data recovered 1981 2010. can look variable names raster. can plot data, eg. climatic water deficit computed Thornthwaite equation.
code: climate_path <- get_chelsa_current(extent = extent,                                   EPSG = epsg,                                   destination = here("vignettes",                                                      "get_started_files"),                                   resolution = 1000,                                   rm_download = FALSE) r_clim <- rast(climate_path) names(r_clim) plot(r_clim$cwd_thornthwaite), range = c(0, 500), main = "CWD Thornthwaite (m)",      cex.main = 2, plg = list(cex = 1), pax = list(cex.axis = 1))

title: Get started with gecevar
text: Now can merge variables one file. Output absolute path gecevar.tif file created.
code: merge_path <- merge_files(environ_path = environ_path,                           climat_path = climat_path,                            destination = "/home/pierre/Bureau/NC")

title: Get started with gecevar
text: Extracted chelsa-climate.org climate data five available models, namely, GFDL-ESM4, IPSL-CM6A-LR, MPI-ESM1-2-HR, MRI-ESM2-0 UKESM1-0-LL. Compute average models SSP choosen.
code: get_chelsa_futur(extent = extent,                  EPSG = epsg,                   destination = "/home/pierre/Bureau/NC",                  resolution = 1000,                  phase = "2071-2100",                  ssp = 585,                  rm_download = FALSE)

title: Variables
text: \[\lambda ET = \frac{\Delta (R_n - G) + \rho_a c_p \frac{(e_s - e_a)}{r_a}}{\Delta + \gamma (1 + \frac{r_s}{r_a})}  \] R_n net radiation, G soil heat flux, (e_s - e_a) represents vapour pressure deficit air, r_a mean air density constant pressure, c_p specific heat air, \(\Delta\) represents slope saturation vapour pressure temperature relationship, \(\gamma\) psychrometric constant, r_s r_a (bulk) surface aerodynamic resistances.

title: Variables
text: \(T_{mean(k)}\) mean temperature month \(k\). \(L\)average day length (hours) month \(k\). \[ = \Sigma^{12}_{= 1} (\frac{T_{mean()}}{5})^{1.514}\] \[ \alpha = (6.75e-7) ^3 - (7.71e-5) ^2 + (1.792e-2) + 0.49239 \] \[ PET_k = 1.6 \frac{L_k}{12} (\frac{10 T_{mean(k)}}{})^{\alpha} \]

title: Variables
text: Climatic Water Deficit (CWD) sum monthly differences potential evapotranspiration precipitation. CWD positive value. higher value CWD indicates higher deficit water. minimal monthly value CWD set 0 precipitation potential evapotranspiration thus water deficit. \[ cwd = \Sigma^{12}_{= 1} max(pet_i - pr_i, 0) \]

title: Variables
text: Number dry months (NDM) annual number months potential evapotranspiration (pet) exceeds precipitation (pr). ’s number 0 12. \[ ndm = \Sigma^{12}_{= 1} \unicode{x1D7D9}_{(pet_i - pr_i > 0)}  \]
